text: Second question! Does the message want you to click on a link? If it does, check the URL carefully to make sure it's what you expect. Scammers often use official-sounding links to get you to give up personal information: however, if you click the address bar, you can see the link and check it's correct.
Check the link to make sure it's OK - for example, a Google website will end with .google.com. You can do this by clicking on the address bar at the top of the screen, and checking the whole link.

That's good! It's important to always be careful when clicking links (especially unexpected ones), so make sure to check before you click. And, if you're already on the page, it's a good ides to check the address bar before you do anything else.
